answerText: chemical potential [prompt on mu][10] This rule can be derived from the Gibbs-Duhem equation. It states that the number of degrees of freedom is equal to the number of components minus the number of its namesake property plus two.
heading: Missiles of October |2011 | Finals 2 | 5 | Science | Chemistry | College
subject: Science
question: Question: For an ideal gas, this quantity is equal to the ideal gas constant times temperature times the logarithm of concentration divided by quantum concentration. For 10 points each: [10] The Gibbs-Duhem equation relates the change in this quantity for individual components in a system to entropy, temperature, volume, and pressure.
